title: 107_hr1621
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001". The Arabia Mountain area in Georgia contains diverse natural, cultural, and historical resources that are worthy of recognition and conservation. Partnerships between public and private entities are seen as the best way to manage these resources. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve and Panola Mountain State Conservation Park protect unique ecosystems and landmarks. The Miners Creek Preserve holds evidence of early human activity. The Miners Creek Preserve in Lithonia, Georgia, contains evidence of early human activity. The city of Lithonia, along with Arabia Mountain and Stone Mountain, showcases the history of granite mining in Georgia. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation, and Lithonia has 2 structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote natural, cultural, and historical resources in the area, including Arabia Mountain and other significant sites. It also aims to assist Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing these resources. The Act aims to assist Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing and implementing a program to protect, enhance, and interpret significant cultural, historical, and land resources within the heritage area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. Establishment of Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. Map available for public inspection. Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance designated as management entity. Authorities and duties of the management entity outlined. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers diverse interests and gives priority to preserving resources within the heritage area. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia is responsible for preserving resources, encouraging land use policies, conducting quarterly public meetings, submitting annual reports, and allowing audits of funds. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must provide records for audit of Federal funds and agreements, and cannot use Federal funds for acquiring real property. They can use funds from other Federal laws for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area that integrates various resources and involves stakeholders. The plan should be based on the preferred concept from the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study and consider state and local plans. It must include an inventory of resources in the area that should be preserved or managed. The management plan for the heritage area should include an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, implementation program, and evaluation of the management entity. This plan must be submitted to the Secretary for approval. The management entity must submit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Failure to do so will result in a halt of additional funding. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of receiving it, in consultation with the State. If the plan is disapproved, revisions must be made. After the initial approval of a management plan, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for revisions to the Secretary within 90 days for approval. The management entity must review and submit recommendations for revisions to the Secretary for approval before implementing any proposed changes using funds from this Act. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. $10,000,000 is authorized for this Act, with a maximum of $1,000,000 per fiscal year, and the Federal share of project costs not exceeding 50 percent. The authority under this Act will terminate after implementation. The Secretary's authority to grant assistance under this Act will end on September 30, 2016.
